title: 113_hr882
content: The Act titled "Contracting and Tax Accountability Act of 2013" prohibits the awarding of Government contracts or grants to individuals or companies with seriously delinquent Federal tax debts. It requires disclosure and evaluation of contract offers from delinquent Federal debtors. The Contracting and Tax Accountability Act of 2013 mandates that executive agencies require bidders to certify they do not have seriously delinquent tax debts when submitting bids for contracts over a certain threshold. Agencies must also consider a certification of seriously delinquent tax debt as definitive proof that the bidder is ineligible for contract consideration. The Contracting and Tax Accountability Act of 2013 mandates that executive agencies must initiate suspension or debarment proceedings against a bidder with a seriously delinquent tax debt certification, or if the certification is found to be false by the Secretary of the Treasury. The head of an agency may waive this requirement in certain circumstances. The Contracting and Tax Accountability Act of 2013 requires executive agencies to take action against bidders with delinquent tax debts. The head of an agency can waive this requirement in urgent situations affecting US interests. The Secretary of the Treasury will provide a standard form for authorization, and regulations must be revised within 270 days of enactment. The Federal Acquisition Regulation will be revised to include the requirements of the Contracting and Tax Accountability Act of 2013 within 270 days of enactment. SEC. 4. DISCLOSURE AND EVALUATION OF GRANT APPLICATIONS FROM DELINQUENT FEDERAL DEBTORS. The head of any executive agency offering grants over a certain threshold must require grant applicants to certify they do not have a seriously delinquent tax debt and authorize disclosure of this information. A certification of a seriously delinquent tax debt is considered definitive proof of high-risk status for grant applicants. The Office of Management and Budget issues guidelines for enhanced oversight of high-risk grantees. Executive agencies must initiate suspension or debarment proceedings against grant applicants with seriously delinquent tax debts or false certifications. Waivers may be granted by agency heads. The head of an executive agency may waive certain requirements for a person in urgent circumstances affecting US interests. A report must be submitted to Congress explaining the waiver decision. The Secretary of the Treasury will provide a standard form for authorization, and regulations must be revised within 270 days. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will revise regulations to incorporate the requirements of this section. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS AND SPECIAL RULES. The term "person" under this Act includes individuals, partnerships, and corporations. However, individuals seeking assistance through a grant entitlement program are excluded from this definition. Additionally, partnerships and corporations with seriously delinquent tax debts are also considered persons under this Act. A corporation is considered a person with a seriously delinquent tax debt if an officer or shareholder holds a majority of outstanding shares and has a seriously delinquent tax debt. The term "seriously delinquent tax debt" refers to an outstanding Federal debt. A "tax debt" is an outstanding Federal debt under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 with a notice of lien filed in public records. Exceptions include debts being paid timely under agreements or those undergoing collection due process hearings or relief requests. The Act will be effective for contracts and grants awarded 270 days after its enactment.
